docs.lead_paragraph: PATRICIA WELLS is The International Herald Tribune's restaurant critic in Paris. Paris still offers some of the world's most charming little hotels. Many are narrow, four-story affairs full of history and legend and sprays of fresh flowers, run by a fiercely proud owner who has dedicated his or her life to restoring, repainting and redecorating the establishment and to welcoming the assortment of international travelers who pass through the city. Many travelers hoard their carefully compiled and hard-earned ''black book'' of small Paris hotels and share the list with only the closest, most deserving friends. When a friend of mine discovered that her preferred hotel would be included in this article, she quickly dispatched a letter revealing an acquaintance's guarded favorite. ''Why should others be spared total exposure?'' she wrote, a bit vexed.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the autumn of 1979, my mother killed the cats. We had seven; one morning, she grabbed four, took them to the vet and had them put to sleep. She said she didn't want to feed them anymore. It occurred to me that she might be going mad. A few months later, she disappeared. When she returned, after four days, she had no idea where she had been. By now, she, too, knew that something was wrong. Over the next two years, she was subjected to periodic memory tests and physical examinations by a battery of general practitioners, gynecologists, neurologists and other physicians. Day by day, she became more disoriented. She would seem surprised at her surroundings, as if she had just appeared there. She stopped cooking, and had difficulty remembering the simplest things. Finally, in September 1981, the neurologist who by then was in charge of the case, told my sister, Margaret, what he had suspected for some time: My mother had Alzheimer's disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: At about 4 o'clock most weekday afternoons, Susan Sarandon starts feeling a little sick to her stomach. Curtain time is just four hours away for a drama in which she plays what she considers to be her most difficult role to date. She portrays a woman assaulted in her home by a would-be rapist in William Mastrosimone's ''Extremities'' at the Westside Arts Center on West 43d Street, a performance that has brought her critical praise. Miss Sarandon - who got an Oscar nomination for her performance in the 1981 film ''Atlantic City'' and acclaim for ''A Coupla White Chicks Sitting Around Talking'' Off Broadway two seasons ago - overpowers her assailant in ''Extremities'' by spraying insect repellent in his eyes. She ties him up and imprisons him in a fireplace.

docs.lead_paragraph: PRESTON STURGES had one of the most meteoric directing careers in movie history, and his life was as freewheeling and urbane as his comedies. He was named Edmond P. Biden at his birth on Aug. 29, 1898, in Chicago, and was educated in private schools, mostly in France. At 16, he became manager of the Deauville branch of his mother's cosmetics company, and a few years later he invented a kissproof lipstick. In New York by the late 1920's, Sturges was writing for the stage.One comedy, ''Strictly Dishonorable,'' was a Broadway hit. In 1933, he went to Hollywood and wrote screenplays, both original and adapted. He pressed Paramount in 1940 to let him direct his own ''Great McGinty.'' Unexpectedly, it was a commercial and critical hit and won Sturges an Oscar for best writing. For the next four years, he was a wonder boy. Sturges's decline was as swift as his rise. In the mid-40's, he left Paramount and entered into a disastrous movie-making partnership with the industrialist Howard Hughes from which he never recovered. Sturges's films began drawing mixed reviews and smaller audiences, and were losing a lot of money. Next, he bought and managed the Players, an early dinner-theater in Hollywood that went broke. After several years of self-exile in France, he started all over again in Manhattan.

headline.main: STURGES FILMS REMEMBERED IN SERIES AT REGENCY

docs.lead_paragraph: The Nicaraguan Government presented today two so-called counterrevolutionary prisoners and a deserter from the Honduran Army who said that United States, Argentine and Honduran military instructors had been advising anti-Sandinist rebel groups based in Honduras. The Government also opened an exhibition of weapons and military equipment, much of it made in the United States, which officials here said had been captured from rebel units that were making frequent incursions into northern Nicaragua. The chief of operations of the state security apparatus, Oscar Loza, said United States Army officers attached to the United States Embassy in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, were directing the counter-revolutionary activities.

headline.main: Sandinist Prisoners Tell of Foreign Advisers

docs.lead_paragraph: For executives in the mass-market paperback book industry, it's just one problem on top of another. Some say their total reading public has declined. Consumers are balking at higher prices. The surging popularity of romance novels, while good for revenues, has created retail bottlenecks. In balance-sheet terms, the problems have been showing up as generally flat net unit sales for several years with a slight slippage in the first 10 months of 1982 - though strong Christmas sales were reported - and modest gains in revenues. And some executives of these paperback companies, whose products include mystery novels, how-to books and celebrity confessions, are voicing concern.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHAT does new mean? And who, everyone wanted to know, qualifies as n ew talent? That was the burning issue last week at a lunch meeting a s the jurors of the Council of Fashion Designers of America gatheredt o decide who in the fashion world should receive that organization'ss econd annual awards. Set up as an alternative to the Coty Awards, which, fraught with confusion and Old Guard favoritism, were traditionally given to the same handful of establishment designers, the council's awards were meant to sweep all that aside with categories and voting practices as clean-cut as a flattop. Nevertheless, confusion reigned and the repartee was, well, almost riveting. As Mary McFadden, the president of the council, an organization of 100 fashion designers and retailers, was about to leave the jurors to their voting and their veal, Oscar de la Renta, a council director, swept in.

docs.lead_paragraph: With much of winter yet to come and spring on the distant horizon, the watchword today in most Seventh Avenue showrooms is summer. This month the last segment of the warm-weather showings, which started in August with clothes for southern resorts, will be introduced to store buyers. The mood is eminently practical, with a bit of levity injected, for summer is a time of travel and vacations. But for the first time in a number of seasons, designers are showing they are aware that clothes for the working woman are necessary during warm weather, in addition to the party and playclothes that are an expected part of the summer agenda.

headline.main: THE SHAPES OF SUMMER FROM FIVE DESIGNERS
